captions.text: MuffinMasterful asks
Is it cheaper to live in Korea than in North America?
I notice how all of your FAPFAPs, the food is generally cheaper.
Is is the same with other expenses as well?
THE FOOD EXPENSE QUESTION!
What are you looking at mister?
What are you doing?
Do you got the crazies?
Guise, we've got a little of the crazies
We've got the crazies
Um...Dr.Meemersworth have been keeping us awake up at night like
Hey I'm a kitty
HEY
HEY
So we are little bit of sleep deprived
If we have a baby
yes, we do have a baby
for a baby kitten
THE EXPENSES!!
Back to expenses
So to you answer your question very generally I'm going to say yes
So that's it for this week's TL:DR
We could get to more detail for how things are cheaper
not everything is cheaper in South Korea
but we find that generally the cost in here is cheaper than North America
But we are from Toronto, Canada
and we could only go from that perspective
And now again, not every part of North America has the same cost
so living in Toronto might be more expensive than living in other parts of America
So I'm not sure where you're specifically from
we only speak from our perspective
Let's start with something easy like transportation
Now, we don't actually drive a car
so we don't know about the insurance for cars
or the gas costs of..
so we can't comment on that
NO, We have a scooter and it's really really cheap
It cost about 4 bucks for every take and it lasts for a month
so we don't drive it that often
So instead, let's look at something like subway system and buses
The basic cost to get on the bus is 90 cent
if you have a swipe card
900 won, so that's a little bit less than 90 cent
But if you just wanna pay it in cash
looking at a 1000won
so that's like a dollar roughly
or roughly like 90 cent
My currency conversion isn't really accurate
I just say that it's almost like a dollar ratio but a little less than that
So that's only a one way ticket
TICKET ONE WAY~ TICKET ONE WAY
But if you're not doing a one way
and you have to go like couple stops and you are heading to another Seoul
It will charge you by distance
The most paid for the subway is probably like a dollar 90
So When we say it's charged by distance
it's not a big amount of money charged for distance
While we are used to in Toronto is only 2 lines
like the east right line and there is a U line
And pretty much if you go one stop over it cost 3 bucks
It's really expensive to use the subway in Toronto
I don't know what it's like in other cities
so please comment on the comment section
so we can complain altogether
but we 100% appreciate the Korean subway system here
It is AWESOME
Next step is TAXIs
We take a lot of taxis because every time we go filming we have a whole lot of gear
like tripods, audio equips, lenses and lights
Like we don't wanna bring that in the subway and take up an entire cart
Especially where the subways are usually really packed
so it's an awkward us to be like
uh..excuse me... we have a cat in our sink
We take taxis a lot
If this was Canada and I take taxis
you'll think I'm pretty loaded
because in our experience taxis are really expensive in Canada
I only remember taking it for like 15 minute ride in Canada
and it cost me like 40 - 50 bucks
The price has gone up really high like quarter
increments in quaters in Cananda
while here in Korea, they start like 2400won which is $2.30 or so
and it goes increments of 10 cents
rather than a quarter
So for example, regular three prizes we work with
We usually do Bucheon to Hong Dae
depending on traffic that day, it costs us around 16-17bucks
sometime it's 13bucks
That's on our good day when we are just like 15minutes over the bridge
Or we go often to Itaewon from Bucheon
and that costs us 23, or 22 bucks to get there
And if go to Gangnam or the Apgujeong area
That will cost us to 30
As soon as you hit the Gangnam area,
you get stuck in the worst traffic in the planet
We gone in all different time of the day
It doesn't matter, there is consistently traffic on the one direction where we are going
So to keep our cat occupied, we're gonna keep her on our shoulders now
so she can stop meowing at us and drinking chemicals
Not sure if this is gonna work
OK Enough about transportation
What's it like to eat in Korea?
Answer : VERY CHEAP!!
We are like looking at a normal meal in Korea
something like Kimbab Cheon Guk or like Kimbab Nara
It's kinda like Korean fast food
But I'm not talking about hamburgers like they have McDonald
and they have BurgerKing and stuff
We're talking Korean food made quickly and cheaply
The price range is between $1.5
and $6 is the most expensive thing that we've seen around, right?
The thing that it amazes us is like for $1.5 you can get a Kimbab
which has actual nutrition value with real rice and real seaweed
and real vegetables inside
I can't think about anything in North America that I can buy with a buck 50
with a nutritional value
like a buck 50 you can get like a bag of chips
or like you can get like a sandwich?
I don't think so
If you don't wanna eat Kimbab roll the whole time
then there is so many other things that you can get in Kimbab Cheon Guk
Most we paid is like 7 bucks for like a super special
that has 3 different things in it but it's still like 7 bucks
no tax on top of it and no tipping on top of that
for like a full meal that we'll get you so stuffed
Now we are talking about kind of fast food type chain right?
But if you wanna go somewhere like grilled meat, like Sam gyup sal or Galbi
or like chicken dish, stuff with like lots of meat in it
Or if you want something like fancy kind of cow cuts
YES You will be paying more money for that
You are looking at a $9 to $15 a person
and they usually weight things by grams
so you will see like how much it ways
It's not like you're getting a random portion size wherever you go
But still that's not like your'e gonna drop it like 100 or 150
If we drop the $100, 150 out in a Korean restaurant
I think that's a month worth of meat
Yah, we would be eating meat for 30 people
and like we would be trashed and like
We'll be eating like kings and queens
It's really , it's really great
When it comes to eating, one thing is that more expensive in South Korea
we found is the produce
like WHOOH,,surprisingly more expensive
We've seen watermelons for 17bucks, 20 bucks
Avocados are not common to get here but when we do find them
they are like 5 bucks for an avocado
One thing that is really good about Korea is that they don't really do seasonal stuff all year around
They only do, literally seasonal
Like you can get watermelon when it's in season, so it's expensive
Once it's out of season, that's it
Right now watermelon we have couple left in the stores
it's gonna be gone
We just can't buy it all year around
We've gotta enjoy it while we can
Speaking of expensive food,
We once ate a 48 Dollar MANGO
by accident
We were grocery shopping and we bought a whole bunch of meat
that we expected that it was gonna be expensive
and we got a mango and we were like "WOW! We haven't had mango for a long time"
"Let's put this on the shopping cart, buy it and go home!"
And then we ate it and was like
"That was a little over right, it wasn't that great mango but at least we had a mango!"
And then we looked at the price at the bottom ..
THAT IS 48 thousand won
When I saw that, I was like, "This gotta be $4.8, it doesn't make sense"
The only reason that we didn't know because that day we had told ourselves in advance
that we're gonna spend a lot of money in meat
We knew this was gonna happen
We are gonna buy salmon, we're gonna buy beef, buy it all
Meanwhile, half of our bill was mango
Now that everyone is going to come to grocery shopping to Korea
so what about things shopping that is usually
shoes, and clothing, and jewelry and accessory
That is kind of iffy
sometimes it's more expensive, sometimes it's lot less expensive
But it is difficult to say that one is heavier than the other
I personally say one is heavier than the other
I would say that lots of stuff is lot cheaper
because if you are looking for named brand,
name brands are expensive wherever you go
So if you go shopping in a department stores, it's gonna be pricey anywhere
I've seen a $120 pair of Levi's here
But yah, Levi's is a name brand and Gucci is a name brand
But I was looking for name brand subway clothing
HUH!
I can get some quality shirts between $5 and $10
They are quite the quality
Hey, is this because you can't buy cute Korean clothing,don't be jealous of me
I can't buy their shoes, shoes are so cheap
Now, cheap goes on the same level
cheap price, cheap quality you know
but the one thing I've notice is that, when I was in Toronto
we used to call things club gear
which was like cheap clothing with club gears
like you wore out dancing but you wouldn't wear it anywhere else
because the quality is not that great
But Korea has really cheap clothing that should be considered club gear because of the price
But it's like adorable, it's like cute
It's like life gear son
NO, It's like a little knit dress with a bows on it like little cherry stuff
That things shouldn't be ten bucks but it is
So underground subway shopping or street shopping
you can get really cheap clothing
Some of the clothing's quality is cheap as well
Same goes for shoes, and earrings and hair bands
You've got the whole range of stuff to go for,
so prepare your suitcases with cheap, everyday life club clothing
Now we can't cover every single living expense in Korea,
we're gonna mention some more in our blogs
If you wanna find more about it,
head on over to eatyourkimchi.com
and we will have a blog post there about it
So that's it for this TL:DR
If you have a question for next week's TL:DR,
leave your question on the comment section below
Or check out the question that is already asked in the comment section
and you can thumb them up to get to our attention
and perhaps we might choose that one
Or perhaps we won't
We are very whimsical that way
Let's enjoy our $6 cup of coffee we've purchased
OH...BOY..

title: Is it Expensive Living in Korea?

comments.author: Victoria Anna

comments.text:
As an Australian born Singaporean-Malaysian I can definitely see where you 
are coming from! Having just spent two months majorly in Singapore you tend 
to notice that areas like Singapore, Korea and Japan have a cheaper 
lifestyle. As you said, I wouldn't expect to get a good meal for under ten 
dollars (it's almost tear-worthy if you do). The idea behind produce, and I 
only state this from my experience in Singapore, is that they don't have 
the resources within their own country and therefore outsource the 
responsibilty to able countries they have trade alliances with and that's 
why it may sometimes be more expensive. Also, as I was visiting, due to the 
floods occurring in Malaysia, one kind of crop could not be available and 
would significantly change the relations between Singapore and Malaysia as 
well as for the people of Singapore whom, if lucky enough would get it at 
an inflated prices. ﻿
comments.author: kelpeater34

comments.text:
Minneapolis MN the metro train is $1.75 for a 2 and a half hour long time

comments.text:

bucks. Los angeles﻿
comments.author: Aaron Kim

comments.text: cant live somewhere with expensive coffee. just, no.﻿
comments.author: Dane Ecklund

comments.text:
+Dane Ecklund they exaggerated it a bit, the Starbucks is ridiculously 
expensive and some of the big chains like Angel-In-Us, Tom and Tom's, and 
Holly's are similarly priced, but the real chill mom and pop shops are way 
cheap (my morning Venti Caramel Macchiato comes out to about $2.75 US) and 
Americanos (because traditional drip coffee is harder to find) can usually 
be found for around $1.25. Also, they live in the heart of Seoul where 
things tend to be a little pricier, whereas I'm kind of on the outskirts so 
location is always a factor.
comments.author: Bob Ruediger

comments.text: NYC $2.75, such bullshit.... and its not even long distance. ﻿

by the way: i was in seoul in 1996 and it was relatively cheaper than

restaurants, and moroever live a more leisured life - going drinking in bar 
louges, using a cab, and so on. now a days i have no idea if it still is 
that cheap.﻿

comments.text:
hello, im from portugal - lisboa- and i think you have done really good

information. and,...thanks for sharing your experience. i only spent 5 
months in seoul, but i didn´t feel like leaving, when i left. and, has i 
was a student at the time, and now im much older - 40- i tend to look upon 
actual american students in korea.- or anybody who goes there - tenderly, 
as if i could totally relate with you...! goodbye, and have fun. sofia 
freitas﻿

in Toronto. My god. I'm in Mississauga right now (around zone 3 distance 
for equivalence) and it costs me $9 to go into Toronto (one way), which is 
around 7 quid?

comments.text:
Not all stuffs are expensives in Malaysia.If the stuffs you buy are 
expensives it means that your place has many rich people.While my place is 
pretty cheap.I once ate noddles at places where rich people live and it 
cost about (Rm)13 dollar.Not cheap at all.While a shop near my house is 
about (Rm)5 dollars and it taste good.And about the flood thingy,Just let 
the prime minister's wife go shop.She's not the prime minister.About the 
golf thingy,He ENCOURAGED us to play golf.That dosen't mean you have to 
play.Don't even say the prime minister and the goverment are stupid.Have 
you thought about the BRIM he gave us every year? it's not that easy to get 
money.BTW,Don't call the goverment racist and so on it is really bad and 
you might get hated on.Trust me i have experience with hateness from a 
ex-friend.

(And yes i DO live in Malaysia and sometimes it's expensives and sometimes 
it isn't)

comments.author: Addy Teddy

comments.text:
In Malaysia everything everything is definately way cheaper compared to 
Korea. A dollar is equivalent to RM3.50. Public transport is cheap too! The 
starting meter for a taxi would be RM3 and it goes up for 10 cent for every 
12seconds or 100meters++ of riding distance. There are a lot of Koreans 
here in Malaysia especially at my campus since it is an international 
private university and they spend money like nobody's business. ﻿

comments.author: alondra diaz (abe)

comments.text:
Here in Romania Transportation is super cheep. For metro or bus a 2 swipe 
ticket is 4 lei that's like a dollar. But in general we buy a monthly 
ticket for 50 lei which is about 13 dollars and you can use it as many 
times as you want for a month. Only thing is you have to wait 5-10 mins 
between swipes. Also student's get 20% discounts. ﻿

comments.author: Handsome von Derpinson

comments.text:
Where I live (Frederick, Maryland.) its.. not bad to ride the bus system, 
the city is so old that they can't build a subway system underneath, and 
also electrical and cable wires are under the city so it would just be a 
lot of work for such a small town. The buses cost 1.50 and you can get a 
transfer to go onto another bus for free. So for me to get to work and back 
home, it cost 3 dollars. I have a bus stamp ticket thing, so its cheaper 
for me. Also, we have buses that go all around Maryland for.. five dollars? 
and also a train that goes to D.C for 6 dollars, I think. So all in all, 
its not bad.﻿
comments.author: Maryann Cockrell

comments.text:
The sort version is as bad as the long version! LOL!!! Also, AS LONG!!! 
Let's see 3 bucks from one subway stop to another dependent on hour of day 
and stop massive delays you've probably heard about in the news to the time 
you're an hour plus late as you have given up and chosen to take the bus. 
They idiotically cut down buses that cut cross county (Silver Spring to 
Shady Grove) and go through Montgomery College so the don't run for about 
an hour plus on the full way and so you have to transfer to three buses 
including a bus that takes you backwards from where you live to get a bus 
going in the direction to the college!!! Those are weekday buses that would 
take you to work at the other side of the world and you have to go half way 
around the other side of the world to get to them!!! Yet on weekends they 
leave those SAME schedules intact with epic schedules that never end full 
way from/to both stations!!! They have done cut backs like that with a lot 
of buses!!! The line I mentioned was metro's Q bus line. The price for me 
is reduced to about half due to my disability smarttrip ($0.90 two buses as 
you get a free ride if you use the transfer in an hour). The regular cash 
fare is like 1.70! For me between stops with my card due to disability 
metro rail can be anywhere from 1-3+ between stops and same, if not more 
for anyone else! Stops are you get on and off and that's end of the line, 
yo do not have to pay to transfer color but for rush hour and non rush the 
fares crazy. It's a MESS!!! You are lucky you just have buses!
comments.author: TheMechanicalGirl999

comments.text: Is it a pain? I never went to DC so I have no idea lol

comments.text:
I live in Montgomery County, MD!!! DO NOT GET ME STARTED ON DC TRANSIT!!! 
LOL!!!

comments.author: applekumi

comments.text: I miss Beijing's subway. ~ $0.33 to get anywhere in the city.﻿

comments.author: Terry Kim

comments.text:
In DC, public transportation is expensive. You can travel on subway and bus 
across not only DC, but MD and VA, but the longer the distance, the more 
you pay. I can go from one end of the line to the other end of the line 
paying around $4 and that's just going one way. But if you're trying to 
save, take the bus. It can be quite a longer ride, sometimes unreliable, 
but a lot cheaper. Paying with cash is like $1.70, but if you pay with a 
card, you only pay $1.60 and you can transfer to any other bus for free as 
long as you travel within a 2 hour time frame. ﻿

comments.author: Sammy Rae Perry

comments.text:
Produce and fruits are expensive in Korea because they're trying to promote 
domestic farming (through use of tax and tariffs). The reason north 
american produce is cheap is because it comes from practically slave labor 
of other countries.﻿
comments.author: ginsengjin

comments.text:
Most of the produce consumed in America is grown in America.  America has a 
vast amount of arable land.  That's why produce and meat is so cheap in 
America.

Korea's extremely high tariffs don't make any sense.  Why put such high 
tariffs on fruits like mangos, pineapples, limes, lemons?  It's not like 
Korean farmers can grow those anyways.  

A lot of the high prices in Korea also have to do with distributors and 
retailers trying make bigger profit margins.  That's why many Koreans now 
shop online and they can purchase name-brand clothes, shoes, and 
accessories for 50% less than what they're sold at Korean department 
stores.  Even Korean electronics are about 50% less overseas, so many 
Koreans order their electronic appliances from foreign companies online and 
then have it shipped to Korea.

comments.author: Lalalalala

comments.text:
Living in Mexico is a lot cheaper, but like said in the video, cheap price, 
cheap quality. We get fruit all year round and mostly all produce(? is very 
cheap, because we have a lot of providers. Public transportation is very 
cheap as opposed to other countries (Around .50 cents in USD for a ride 
maybe) but you have to be willing to be groped, shoved, nearly killed and 
in the middle of a tight mass of sweaty humans. Not pleasant.
As for clothes and such, depending on where you get them, they can be 
really cheap or really expensive, depending usually on brands and quality. 
For a normal worker, life here can be pretty expensive. ﻿
comments.author: Lyra Misty

comments.text:

I live in St.Catharines, ONT about an hour away from Toronto, and before 
Public Transit was $2.50 for a singular bus ride (you can get a transfer 
that gives you one free ride, but you have to use it within an hour of 
getting it), now the bus costs $3.00. CRAZY! what's even worse is if I 
forget my student I.D. card (you can swipe it for free bus rides) I would 
have to pay $6.00 to get to my College! It's preposterous because the ride 
only takes 15 minutes (or less, depending on traffic that day)! I'M ALREADY 
PAYING THOUSANDS OF DOLLARS TO LEARNNN! D''': ﻿
